metadata.title: Sonochemical procedures; the main synthetic method for synthesis of coinage metal ion supramolecular polymer nano structures

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Ultrasonics Sonochemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /u l tson
Review
Sonochemical procedures; the main synthetic method for synthesis of coinage metal ion supramolecular polymer nano structures
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ultsonch.2015.12.003 1350-4177/ 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: akhbari.k@khayam.ut.ac.ir (K. Akhbari).
Fatemeh Shahangi Shirazi, Kamran Akhbari ⇑

sections.heading: School of Chemistry, College of Science, University of Tehran, P.O. Box 14155-6455, Tehran, Islamic Republic of Iran
sections.text: a r t i c l e i n f o

sections.heading: Article history:
sections.text: Received 17 October 2015 Received in revised form 5 December 2015 Accepted 6 December 2015 Available online 8 December 2015

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Sonochemical process Nano Supramolecular polymer Copper Silver Gold
a b s t r a c t
During the last two decades, supramolecular polymers have received great attention and the number of their synthesized compounds is still growing. Although people have long been interested in their crystalline network form it was only until 2005 that the first examples of nano- or microscale coordination polymers particles be demonstrated. This review tries to give an overview of all nano supramolecular compounds which were reported from coinage metal ions, their attributed synthetic procedures and to investigate the relation between the dimensions of coinage metal ions (Cu, Ag and Au) coordination and supramolecular polymers with their nano-structural morphologies and dimensions. Eleven compounds (from twenty compounds) with nano-structure morphology were prepared by sonochemical process and Ag(I) coordination and supramolecular polymer nano-structures can be easily prepared by sonochemical procedures.
2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A metal–organic coordination polymer defines as a coordination compound continuously extending in 1, 2 or 3 dimensions through coordination bonds [1]. They are a new family of crystalline materials which are attracting increasing interest owing to their fascinating and diverse topologies, and potential applications relevant to gas storage, catalysis, molecular adsorption, nonlinear optics, molecular sensing, luminescence, separation and magnetic materials [2–7]. The assembly of coordination polymers is primarily driven by coordination bonds, dependent upon the selection of metal ions and organic bridging ligands with specific coordination
habits [8]. In many cases, non-covalent intermolecular forces, such as hydrogen bonding and p–p stacking also play important roles in stabilizing the coordination polymers or assembling the coordination substructure into 3D supramolecular architecture [9–12]. Coordination polymers not only have a series of properties and potential applications themselves, but also can be precursors to be converted to related metal oxides with more applications in magnetic devices, catalysis, super capacitors, lithium ion batteries, etc. under certain conditions [13,14]. Although people have long been interested in their crystalline network form it was only until 2005 that the first examples of nano- or microscale coordination polymers particles (CPPs) be demonstrated [15]. There are many methods for the preparation of nanomaterials including hydrothermal or solvothermal methods, microwave-solvothermal synthesis, microwave synthesis, magnetic-field-assisted hydrothermal,
sol–gel process, electrochemically induced sol–gel, microemulsion and reverse micelle/microemulsion, homogeneous precipitation method, cluster growth method, chemical vapor deposition, vapor– liquid–solid process, soft chemical method, electrophoretic deposition, electrochemical fabrication, chemical reduction method, electrolysis of metal salts, rapid expansion of supercritical solvents, photoreduction of metal ions, microwave plasma synthesis, mechanochemical process and sonochemical method [16]. Sonochemistry deals with the chemistry that takes place upon application of high-energy ultrasound to a reaction mixture. Ultrasound is cyclic mechanical vibration with a frequency between 20 kHz
and 10 MHz. Since the wavelength is much larger than molecular dimensions, no direct interaction between ultrasound and molecules can be responsible for chemical reactions, but when highenergy ultrasound interacts with liquids, cyclic alternating areas of compression (high pressure) and rarefaction (low pressure) are formed. In the low pressure region, the pressure drops below the vapor pressure of the solvent and/or the reactants and small bubbles, i.e. cavities, are formed. The bubbles grow under the alternating pressure through the diffusion of solute vapor into the volume of the bubble. Thus, ultrasonic energy is accumulated. Once the bubbles reach their maximum size, they become unstable and collapse.
aphs of compound 3 nano-structure prepared using ultrasound method. Reproduced
This process of bubble formation, growth, and collapse is called cavitation and it leads to the rapid release of energy with heating and cooling rates of >1010 K s 1, temperatures of 5000 K and pressures of 1000 bar. Thus, these ‘‘hot spots” present rather unusual conditions of short duration of extremely high temperature and pressures inside the collapsing bubble as well as in its vicinity (ring of 200 nm). In this work, we wish to investigate the various methods which were applied for synthesis of coinage metal ions (Cu, Ag and Au) coordination and supramolecular polymer nano-structures and to evaluate the relation between the dimensions of them with their nano-structural morphologies and dimensions. Among coinage metal coordination polymers, copper(II) coordination polymers are of considerable interest because of their appealing structural and photoluminescent biological function, catalytic, luminescence and
Fig. 2. (a) Preparation nanoparticles of Cu–BMSB–Cu (6), addition of diethyl ether or pen particle formation and precipitation. (b) SEM image of spherical particles of 6. Reproduc
magnetic properties [17]. Silver(I) is extensively exploited as a metal component with d10 configuration which exhibits a variety of coordination numbers ranging from 2 to 8. Thus the coordination geometries are also as varied as linear, T-shaped, seesaw type, square pyramidal, trigonal bipyramidal, octahedral and other geometries [18]. The overall structural arrangement of the participating components in the silver(I)-based coordination polymers (AgCPs) are influenced by the ligand design [19], counter anion [20], metal to ligand ratio [21] and a few other parameters. In AgI supramolecular chemistry, secondary interactions such as Ag C, Ag Ag and Ag H also exist which distinguish AgI supramolecular polymers from other supramolecular compounds [22]. The properties of AgCPs include photoluminescence [23], photochromism [24], catalysis [25], conduction [26] and antibiotic activities [27].
tane into the reaction mixture containing Cu2+ and Cu–BMSB in pyridine results in ed with permission of Nature publishing group.
Au(I) supramolecular polymers are known to be highly emissive under certain circumstances [28–30] and there are many cases in which Au(I)-based luminescence has been harnessed as a sensor [31]. For example, dicyanoaurate, [Au(CN)2] , is a useful building block for creating heterobimetallic coordination polymers as functional materials, such as luminescent sensors, due to the sensitive dependence of the emission energy on the Au–Au distance, which changes upon the addition of an analyte [32].

sections.heading: 2.1. Cu(II) supramolecular polymers
sections.text:
The hydrothermal reaction of copper(II) acetate and btcH3 leads to the formation of a one-dimensional coordination polymer, [Cu (btcH)(H20)3]n (1) (btcH3 = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid). The copper (II) ion is coordinated by two monodentate carboxylic groups of different acid molecules and three water molecules,
produced with permission of The Royal Society of chemistry.
CTAB: (a) 0; (b) 0.005; (c) 0.01; and (d) 0.05. The insets in the SEM pictures are yal Society of chemistry.

solvent [37]

Fig. 5. (a) A fragment of 1D pencil shape coordination polymer of 11 (Ag = violet, O = red, C = gray, H = white). (b) SEM images of compound 11 nanorods. Reproduced with permission of The Royal Society of chemistry.
which results in a 5-coordinate complex. The similar reaction by sonochemical method leads to the formation of nano-sized form of 1. SEM (scanning electron microscope) images showed that the nano-coordination polymer is highly uniform in shape, exhibiting particle morphology [33]. In another work, mesoporous nanostructured metal–organic hybrid material of copper(II) ion with PPD (PPD = Phenylenediamine) as the organic ligand was synthesized at room temperature. The proposed formula of the compound is {[Cu(H2O)4(PPD)2]2+ 2Cl }n (2). In this one-dimensional coordination polymer, the Cu(II) ion binds to four oxygen atoms from the four coordinated water molecules (which come from aqueous medium) and two nitrogen atoms from two different PPD ligands in the distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Attempts to synthesis nano-structure of 2, result in formation of
Fig. 6. (a) SEM images of compound 14 nanorods obtained by 0.05 M concentration of i with permission of Elsevier.
nanoparticles from this one-dimensional coordination polymer which was determined by SEM [34]. Morsali et al. reported the crystal structure of Cu(II) one-dimensional coordination polymer, [Cu(dpa)(N3)2]n (3) (dpa = 2,20-dipyridylamid) (Fig. 1a) which shows Cu(II) is bridged by a single EO–N3 and another N3 as the terminal ligand. Compound 3 has been synthesized by the reaction of dpa and mixture of Cu(ClO4)2 6H2O and sodium azide under ultrasonic irradiation, too [35]. The SEM image shows the formation of pellet-like nano-particles of 3 under ultrasound irradiation (Fig. 1b). In [Cu(C6H4NO2)(OH)]H2O (4), each copper atom is fivecoordinated with four oxygen atoms (three from m-OH and the rest from the carboxylate group of isonicotinic acid) and one nitrogen atom from the other isonicotinic unit. Each isonicotinic acid ligand bridges two copper ions by an oxygen atom and nitrogen
nitial precursor. (b) A fragment of the two-dimensional network in 14. Reproduced
atom to form a one-dimensional chain-like structure extending along the a axis and these chains are parallel to each other by p– p stacking interaction and hydrogen bonds to constructing the two-dimensional supramolecular polymer. Cu Cu interactions also exist in 4. Fan et al. also synthesized nanorods of 4 in the absence of surfactant via a hydrothermal method [36]. They also reported one-dimensional coordination polymer of Cu(C6H4NO2)2(H2O)4 (5). In 5, each copper atom is six-coordinated with four aqua oxygen atoms constituting an equatorial plane and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms at the two vertexes. The equatorial plane in the crystalline structure of compound 5 would make it grow along the direction of four coordinated water molecules and lead to the formation of the final two-dimensional (2D) butterfly-like nanosheets of 5. In a word, the growth of coordination polymer nanostructures is mainly driven by self-assembly of the crystal structure with isonicotinic acid as a ligand in the absence of surfactant via a hydrothermal method [36]. Three-dimensional coordination polymer Cu–BMSB–Cu (6) (where M and M0 = Cu2+, R = CO2, BMSB = binaphthyl bis-metallo-tridentate Schiff base) have been synthesized by the reaction of Cu2+(OAc)2 and Cu–BMSB (where M = Cu2+, R = CO2H) (Fig 2a) [37]. Mirkin and colleagues discovered the formation of micro- or nanoparticles from connecting Cu2+ ion with carboxylate functionalized binaphthyl bis-metallo-tridentate Schiff base (BMSB) building blocks that was determined by SEM (Fig 2b) [37]. In another work, one-dimensional nanorods of 3D porous coordination polymer {[Cu2(BDC-NH2)2(dabco)]DMF 3H2O} (7) (BDC-NH2 = amino benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate), which has paddlewheel structure and CuO4NCu coordination environment, have been synthesized in the presence of acetic acid as a modulator via sonochemical method. Ultrasound irradiation helps to nucleation step of the oriented attachment of modulation method to prepared nanorods of compound 7. This work was the first report for synthesis of nanosized compound of 7 by coupling of the sonochemical and the modulation methods [38]. The novel crystal structure of three-dimensional {[Cu(en)2][KFe(CN)6]}n (8) using [Cu(en)2]2+ as a template and K+ as a connecting unit was reported by S. Wu. The SEM images shown nanorods of 8 obtained from the direct reaction of two precursors solutions. The as-prepared nanorods are irregular and without uniform size. By adding PVP into the K3[Fe(CN)6] aqueous solution, the morphologies of the nanocrystals can been changed from nanorods to microcubes. The result indicated the remarkable effect of PVP on the crystallization of 8 micro-arrowhead. It seems that PVP and ultrasonic radiation played a key role in the morphology development of the nano/ micro-crystals. PVP acts not only as a stabilizer but also as a shape and size controller [39]. Sun and co-workers provided a facile and rapid method to synthesize morphology- and size-controlled nano/ microscale porous 3D coordination polymer of [Cu3(btc)2] (9) (btcH3 = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) which has a paddlewheel structure and CuO4Cu coordination environment. The nucleation rate of [Cu3(btc)2] crystals slows down in the presence of CTAB (CTAB = cetyltrimethylammonium bromide), which results in crystals of large size. With the amount of CTAB increased, the retardation of nucleation is more significant, and thus larger sized crystals were obtained. As a result, the existence of CTAB not only slows down the growth rate to form different crystal morphologies, but also slows down the nucleation rate to produce larger sized particles (Fig. 3). Fig. 4a shows that the particles obtained without addition of CTAB have cubic shapes. When the concentration of CTAB reached 0.005 M, the particle morphology changed to truncated cubes (Fig. 4b). As shown in Fig. 4c, when the concentration of CTAB increased to 0.01 M, thus the morphology turned to cuboctahedrons. Fig. 4d shows that the morphology of particles is truncated octahedrons, from increasing the concentration of CTAB to 0.05 M [40]. Micro sheet-like particles of [Cu(terpyOH)2] (HBTC) 2H2O (10) (terpyOH = 40-hydroxy 2,20:60,200-terpyridine,
BTC = 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate) were prepared by hydrothermal method and characterized by X-ray single crystal structural analysis. A variety of hydrogen bonds constructing the 3D supramolecular polymer. The structure of 10 contains four independent units, one dication [CuII(4-terpyOH)2]2+, one HBTC2 anion and two H2O molecules, as solvents of crystallization. The Cu(II) center in 10 is hexacoordinated octahedral geometry in which
three nitrogens of each of the two enolic terpyOH molecules chelate to the metal ion. The [Cu(terpyOH)2]2+ cations and the HBTC2 anions interact with each other to form 1D channels through p–p and H-bonding interactions along a-axis. Inside the channel, the lattice water molecules forming a zigzag water chain as guests are filled in the channel via hydrogen bonds. The fact that water chains fill in the channels, suggests that water chains may influence the arrangement of the three-dimensional infinite network [41]. A summary of the contents about Cu(II) supramolecular polymers can be find in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Ag(I) supramolecular polymers
sections.text:
SEM images of compound [Ag2(l5-TPOAc)2]n (11) (TPOAc
= triphenylacetate) which prepared by sonochemical process, show the nano rods morphology (Fig. 5b) [42]. Structure of 11 shows the formation of a 1D pencil shape organometallic coordination polymer (Fig. 5a). There are two types of Ag+-ions with the coordination number of five and seven, which form strong g2-Ag2-Cp bonds and two weak g1-Ag1 Cp interactions. Strong Ag-Ag interactions also exist in 11. [Ag(l-bpfb)(NO3)]n (12) (bpfb = N,N-bis(4-pyridylfor mamide)-1,4-benzene) is another one-dimensional silver(I) coordination polymer, which its nano rods were synthesized by sonochemical method [43]. Secondary hydrogen bonding and p–p stacking interactions grows 12 into a three dimensional supramolecular network. In addition to Ag–N bonds in compound 12, every silver(I) ion forms four weak Ag–Onitrate interactions and the geometry of Ag(I) atoms is distorted octahedral. The onedimension chains connect to each other by hydrogen bonding and grow in second dimension like a square grid with bent lines view. In another work, agglomerated nanoparticles of twodimensional coordination polymer, [Ag(l3-Hma)]n (13) (H2ma = maleic acid), has been synthesized by the reaction of KHma and AgNO3 by sonochemical process. The single-crystal X-ray data of compound 13 shows the formation of hemi paddlewheel structure around Ag(I) ions. Compound 13 contains silver atoms with threefold coordination and an O3Ag AgO3 coordination environment. Structure of compound 13 could be consider as a parallel one-dimensional corrugated tape polymers along a axis which is connected to each other and form 2D network. Hydrogen bonding interactions present between –OH and –COO– groups of Hma– ligand in 13 [44]. Nano rods of an organometallic coordination polymer of [Ag(l4-DPOAc)]n (14) (DPOAc = diphenylacetate) with a less-common g1-coordination mode of the phenyl rings was synthesized by the reaction of DPOAcK and AgNO3 by sonochemical process, too (Fig. 6) [45]. It appears that an argentophilic interaction also exists in 14. Thus compound 14 can be considered to contain silver atoms with fourfold coordination and an O3CAg AgO3C environment. The structure of compound 14 may also be considered as one-dimensional linear chains constructed of carboxylate group bridging, running parallel to the b axis and the individual
polymeric chains are almost parallel to each other and further bridged by Ag–C bonds, resulting in a two-dimensional framework. In another work, nanoparticles of an organosilver(I) coordination polymer, [Ag2(l8-SB)]n (15) (H2SB = 4-[(4-hydroxyphenyl)sulfo nyl]-1-benzenol), with a less-common g4-coordination mode of the phenyl rings, in addition to the normal phenolic coordination modes were synthesized by sonochemical method (Fig. 7) [46]. In compound 15, the phenolic oxygen atoms of the SB2 ligand act as bi-donor bridging atoms where each oxygen atom of the Ph-O groups link to two different silver(I) ion (Fig 7c). The AgI coordination sphere is augmented to four and rather than exhibiting a AgO2 coordination sphere, the compound can be considered to have a bihapto (O2C2Ag) center with coordination number of four. The silver atoms interact with the p electrons of the aromatic rings. The individual polymeric chains are almost parallel to each other and further bridged via the Ag–C bonds, resulting in a threedimensional framework (Fig 7c). The single-crystal X-ray data of [Ag2(l2-py-4-c)2]n (16) (py-4-c– = pyridine-4-carboxylate) shows the formation of three-dimensional interpenetrated silver(I) coordination polymer which has two types of AgI ions with O2NAg1 O2H, N2Ag2 O2H2 coordination spheres. Synthesis process of it under ultrasonic irradiation results in formation threedimensional coordination polymer of 16 with nano rods morphology [47]. Agglomerated nanoparticle of [Ag(Me-8-HqH)(Me-8-Hq)]n (17) (Me-8-HqH = 2-methyl-8-hydroxyquinoline) supramolecular polymer with one-dimensional chain structure, as a result of hydrogen bonding interaction, were synthesized by the reaction of Me-8-HqH and AgNO3 by sonochemical process. Concentration increase of initial reagents results in agglomeration of compound 17 nano-structures [48]. Coordination numbers of AgI ions in compound 17 are four and they have AgO2N2 coordination spheres. The AgI complexes in 17 are linked to each other via hydrogen bonding and finally form a supramolecular chain structure. In [Ag(8-HqH)(8-Hq)]n (18) (8-HqH = 8-hydroxyquinoline, 8-Hq = 8-hydroxyquinolate), the AgI complexes were linked to each other via hydrogen bonding to form a supramolecular chain (1D) structure. The AgI ions in compound 18 also be involved in two g1 interactions with the phenyl group of neighboring [Ag(8-HqH)(8-Hq)] units. Thus, the complex could be considered to contain an O2N2Ag C2 coordination sphere [49]. Solid–gas reaction of compound 18 with HNO3 results in formation two-dimensional supramolecular polymer of {[Ag(8-HqH)2]NO3}n (19). Compound 18 nano-particles were prepared from gas–solid reaction of NH3 hydrated vapors with {[Ag(8-HqH)2]NO3}n (19). Two types of AgI ions exist in 19. The AgI ions contain a tetrahapto center with an O2N2Ag C4 square-planar coordination sphere. These 2 g2-Ag C interactions result in the formation of parallel chains in 19. When 18 under goes a solid–gas reaction with HNO3 vapors, compound 19 nano-particle were formed [49]. A summary of the contents about Ag(I) supramolecular polymers can be find in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.3. Au(I) supramolecular polymers
sections.text: Lamellar two-dimensional coordination polymer of Au(I)–MPA (20) (MPA = Au(I)-3-mercaptopropionate) turned into nanosheets and nanostrings using different amount of sodium citrate as an exfoliation agent by chemical exfoliation method (Fig. 8). With the addition of CA–Na, nanosheets were observed then with the increasing amount of CA–Na, a new structure of nanostring appeared. TEM images of Au(I)–MPA nanostructures with CA–Na to Au molar ratios of 5, 20 showed in Fig 9a and b respectively. The transformation of these nanostructures is dominated by adjusting the multiple interactions in system, such as hydrogen bond interaction, Au(I)–Au(I) interaction and Au–S coordinate interaction. The static repulsion between the ligands is strong enough to break the Au(I)–Au(I) bonds by increasing the Au–Au distance. This change would finally affect the Au(I)–S coordination modes [50]. Uv–Vis spectroscopy has been explored as a timeresolved method for monitoring the assembly of Au(I)-MPA CPs too [51] (Table 3).

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
In Summary, it seems that Cu(II) coordination polymers has more tendency to form nano particles rather than other nano structures. In Ag(I) ion, 1D, 2D and 3D coordination polymers usually tend to be formed in nano rod morphology and they are less likely to form nanoparticles. No nano sheet morphology was observed for Ag(I) coordination and supramolecular polymers. The tendency to form supramolecular polymers in Ag(I) ion is more than Cu(II) ion. 1D Ag(I) coordination polymers, can be formed in nano rod morphology. Finally the only observed nanostructure from Ag(I) supramolecular polymers is nanoparticles. Lamellar twodimensional coordination polymer of Au (20) due to its structural characteristics tends to form nano-sheets (2D) morphology and in
their nano-structure dimensions.
amore difficult condition, tends to form nano-strings (1D). Finally it seems that both the two factors of (i) the synthetic methods and conditions and (ii) self-assembly of initial units play important roles in formation of coinage metal ion supramolecular polymer nanostructures. In addition, it is found that sonochemical procedure is an excellent, easy, effective and green method for synthesis of coinage metal ion supramolecular polymer nano-structures.

referenceMentions.context: A metal–organic coordination polymer defines as a coordination compound continuously extending in 1, 2 or 3 dimensions through coordination bonds [1].
The assembly of coordination polymers is primarily driven by coordination bonds, dependent upon the selection of metal ions and organic bridging ligands with specific coordination habits [8].

Although people have long been interested in their crystalline network form it was only until 2005 that the first examples of nano- or microscale coordination polymers particles (CPPs) be demonstrated [15].

sol–gel process, electrochemically induced sol–gel, microemulsion and reverse micelle/microemulsion, homogeneous precipitation method, cluster growth method, chemical vapor deposition, vapor– liquid–solid process, soft chemical method, electrophoretic deposition, electrochemical fabrication, chemical reduction method, electrolysis of metal salts, rapid expansion of supercritical solvents, photoreduction of metal ions, microwave plasma synthesis, mechanochemical process and sonochemical method [16].
Thus the coordination geometries are also as varied as linear, T-shaped, seesaw type, square pyramidal, trigonal bipyramidal, octahedral and other geometries [18].

The overall structural arrangement of the participating components in the silver(I)-based coordination polymers (AgCPs) are influenced by the ligand design [19], counter anion [20], metal to ligand ratio [21] and a few other parameters.

The overall structural arrangement of the participating components in the silver(I)-based coordination polymers (AgCPs) are influenced by the ligand design [19], counter anion [20], metal to ligand ratio [21] and a few other parameters.
In Ag supramolecular chemistry, secondary interactions such as Ag C, Ag Ag and Ag H also exist which distinguish Ag supramolecular polymers from other supramolecular compounds [22].
The properties of AgCPs include photoluminescence [23], photochromism [24], catalysis [25], conduction [26] and antibiotic activities [27].

Au(I) supramolecular polymers are known to be highly emissive under certain circumstances [28–30] and there are many cases in which Au(I)-based luminescence has been harnessed as a sensor [31].

For example, dicyanoaurate, [Au(CN)2] , is a useful building block for creating heterobimetallic coordination polymers as functional materials, such as luminescent sensors, due to the sensitive dependence of the emission energy on the Au–Au distance, which changes upon the addition of an analyte [32].

metadata.abstractText: During the last two decades, supramolecular polymers have received great attention and the number of their synthesized compounds is still growing. Although people have long been interested in their crystalline network form it was only until 2005 that the first examples of nanoor microscale coordination polymers particles be demonstrated. This review tries to give an overview of all nano supramolecular compounds which were reported from coinage metal ions, their attributed synthetic procedures and to investigate the relation between the dimensions of coinage metal ions (Cu, Ag and Au) coordination and supramolecular polymers with their nano-structural morphologies and dimensions. Eleven compounds (from twenty compounds) with nano-structure morphology were prepared by sonochemical process and Ag(I) coordination and supramolecular polymer nano-structures can be easily prepared by sonochemical procedures. 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
